awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Undergraduate Summer Research in Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Marquette University, located in Milwaukee, WI, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2017- 2019. Students will choose from a variety of research projects working with faculty in the Department of Biological Sciences. Projects will address biological questions in a range of diverse model systems using cellular, molecular, genetic, and structural techniques. Students will learn to read the scientific literature and develop communication skills through weekly journal clubs, laboratory group meetings, and research discussions. Students will also participate in workshops on responsible research conduct, career opportunities, and the graduate school application process. Students will present their findings at both a poster session and research symposium. Networking activities will be interwoven throughout the program to promote a sense of community among faculty, and the REU participants. Students are selected based on their interest in research, academic record, and phone interviews with potential faculty mentors. Members of underrepresented minority groups and students from colleges with limited research opportunities are especially encouraged to apply.

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Together, the research and associated activities of this program are expected to increase retention of participating students in STEM disciplines and increase diversity of the nation's scientific workforce. More immediately, the results of the research will be shared with the Marquette community, the students' home institutions and the broader scientific community. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. 

A common web-based assessment tool (SALG URSSA) used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://www.marquette.edu/biology/srp.shtml or by contacting the PI (Dr. Allison Abbott at allison.abbott@marquette.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Edward Blumenthal at edward.blumenthal@marquette.edu).

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
This award supported a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site in Interdisciplinary Undergraduate Summer Research in Biology in the Department of Biological Sciences at Marquette University. 

The first goal of the REU site was to provide a high-quality and comprehensive summer research experience to undergraduate students. During the summers of 2017-2019, the award directly supported the participation of 30 students in our summer program and allowed the participation of an additional 20 students from the host institution who were supported by institutional and investigator funds. Students conducted independent research projects for 10 weeks on a wide range of topics related to evolution, genetics, cell and molecular biology, and biochemistry, working directly with faculty mentors. During the program, students presented their work in a poster session, which included undergraduates doing research in Chemistry, Physics, Mathematics, Statistics, and Computer Science as well as students at a nearby institution, Lakeland University. Other activities included workshops focused on the Responsible Conduct of Research, graduate school admission process, and in weekly journal clubs. Weekly dinners included a range of discussions including topics centered on the place of science in society, career stories by faculty mentors, and other activities designed to provide opportunities for students to experience life in research science and develop an identity as a scientist.

 The second goal of the REU site was to provide a summer research experience to students that had limited research opportunities at their home institutions and to members of minority groups that are underrepresented in science. Twenty-five of the 30 students were enrolled in institutions that did not have PhD programs in the Biological Sciences. Twelve of the 30 students were members of underrepresented minority groups.

The third goal of the REU site was to promote participants? choice of a research-related career. Of the REU-funded students, all 30 have completed their undergraduate degrees. 10 of these 30 students are now in research-related careers, including 8 who are currently enrolled in doctoral programs in biology or a related field. Eight graduated students are enrolled in professional programs in health-related fields or are employed in the health care field. As another means of assessing the impact of the program, students responded to a survey at the end of the summer. Following are the mean values of student satisfaction or learning gains with respect to different aspects of the program: for ?the research experience overall?, the mean response as 3.7 (using a scale of 1-4 with 4 indicating ?excellent?), for ?Understanding what everyday research work is like??4.5 and for ?confidence in my ability to do research??4.5 (using a scale of 1-5 with 5 indicating ?great gain?), and for ?feeling like a scientist??4.7 (using a scale of 1-5 with 5 indicating ?a great deal?).

In summary, the REU site in Interdisciplinary Undergraduate Summer Research in Biology at Marquette University that was supported by this award achieved its goals.

Modified by: Allison L Abbott
